summary: Interactive romantic Valentine web page (HTML/CSS/JS) with a customized prompt text (“Will you be kannettan’s valentine”), evasive No button, and a custom image shown after clicking Yes; designed to run on mobile and desktop browsers (Chrome/Safari) with a pink/white theme.
architectural_notes: Implement as a self-contained HTML/CSS/JS page suitable for running locally in mobile/desktop browsers (Chrome/Safari).
Ensure the evasive “No” interaction uses mobile-friendly events (pointerdown/touchstart) and repositions randomly while keeping the button within viewport bounds.
Support swapping the Yes-result image with a user-provided static asset (stored locally with the frontend assets and referenced directly).
Success/result view must reference and display only the exact user-provided attached image asset (no substitutions or generated placeholders).
Success/result view after clicking “Yes” must display ONLY the exact user-attached image file (kanni 14.PNG) and must not show any other/AI/generated placeholder images.
User confirmed the required success image filename is exactly "Kanni 14.PNG"; treat filename as case-sensitive and reference it exactly in the success/result view asset path.
known_issues: Result view is displaying an incorrect image after clicking “Yes” instead of the exact user-provided attached image; needs to render the provided static asset reliably.

Conflicting asset requirement: project state/imageRequirements mention swapping success image to “kanni 14-1.PNG”, but user explicitly mandates displaying only the attached “kanni 14.PNG” on the Yes-result view.
The required success image file ("kanni 14.PNG") is missing/not present in the project’s assets directory at runtime, so the Yes-result view has nothing to load and shows no image.
Potential filename case mismatch: user confirmed "Kanni 14.PNG" (capital K) while project references "kanni 14.PNG"; case-sensitive environments may fail to load the image.
Build/deployment is failing with an internal configuration error (“Please inform the Caffeine team”), blocking verification of the Yes-result image display.

existing_features.title: Create a single-page romantic Valentine prompt UI that asks the visitor to be the user's Valentine, using a pink-and-white romantic theme and ensuring it is responsive and usable on mobile (Android/iPhone) and desktop in Chrome and Safari.

Implement the “No” option as an evasive interactive element that moves away when the user attempts to interact with it (hover/pointer enter on desktop; touch start / pointer down on mobile), preventing the user from clicking it.
When the user clicks “Yes”, replace the prompt UI with a celebratory result view that displays a meme image and the text: “Good choice ❤️”.
Add the required meme image to the frontend as a static generated asset under frontend/public/assets/generated and render it directly from the frontend (no backend image serving).

Update the Valentine prompt UI so the “No” button is rendered visually below the “Yes” button on all screen sizes (mobile and desktop), while preserving the existing romantic theme and responsive layout.
Ensure the “No” button moves to a random new position whenever the user tries to click/tap it, and that this evasive behavior reliably works on smartphones (touch/pointer interactions).
Update the main prompt headline text on the initial Valentine screen from “Will you be my Valentine?” to exactly: “Will you be kannettan's valentine” (including the apostrophe).

On the success/result view (shown after clicking “Yes”), display the user-uploaded image (kanni 14.PNG) inside the existing image container instead of the current meme image, using a static asset under frontend/public/assets/generated.

Update the success/result view (shown after clicking “Yes”) to render the exact image the user attached (the user-uploaded image referenced as “kanni 14.PNG”) instead of the currently displayed generated image.

Ensure the frontend/public/assets/generated directory contains the exact attached image file that should be shown on the success screen, and remove/stop referencing any incorrect image asset currently used for that purpose.
Add the newly attached image file exactly as-is to the static assets directory at frontend/public/assets/generated/ with the exact filename "kanni 14-1.PNG".

Update the success/result view (shown after clicking “Yes”) to render the image from "/assets/generated/kanni 14-1.PNG" and stop referencing any other success image filename (including "/assets/generated/kanni 14.PNG").

Update the success/result view shown after clicking “Yes” to render ONLY the image at "/assets/generated/kanni 14-2.PNG" and stop referencing any other success image filenames (including "/assets/generated/kanni 14-1.PNG" and "/assets/generated/kanni 14.PNG").

Update the success/result view shown after clicking “Yes” to render ONLY the image at the exact path "/assets/generated/kanni 14.PNG" and stop referencing any other success image filenames (including the currently referenced "/assets/generated/kanni 14-2.PNG").

Add the user-uploaded image file (currently uploaded as "kanni 14-4.PNG") to the frontend static assets directory at "frontend/public/assets/generated/" and ensure it is available at runtime under the exact filename "Kanni 14.PNG" (capital K, space, and .PNG extension).

Update the success/result view shown after clicking “Yes” to load the image from the exact path "/assets/generated/Kanni 14.PNG" and ensure the UI does not reference any other success image filenames.

Make the success/result view reliably display the image asset even when the filename contains spaces by updating the src to use a URL-encoded path for the exact case-sensitive filename "Kanni 14.PNG" under "/assets/generated/".
Add explicit runtime error handling for the success/result image so that if the image fails to load, the UI shows a clear English fallback message and preserves the rest of the success layout.

Ensure the frontend static assets include the success image file in the deployable public directory at the exact path "frontend/public/assets/generated/Kanni 14.PNG" (capital K, space, .PNG extension), and remove/avoid any references on the success screen to other similarly-named files (e.g., "kanni 14.PNG", "kanni 14-1.PNG", "kanni 14-2.PNG").

new_feature_requests.summary: Build a simple romantic-themed interactive Valentine webpage that asks the user to be the Valentine (single purpose).
Add Yes/No options where the No button moves away on hover to prevent clicking.
On Yes click, display a meme image with the text “Good choice ❤️”.
Use a pink and white romantic color scheme and ensure compatibility on Android/iPhone and web via Chrome and Safari.
Place the “No” button below the “Yes” button and make it move to a random position when the user tries to click/tap it, including on smartphones.
Update the main prompt text to: “Will you be kannettan’s valentine”.
On Yes click, display the user-provided image inside the result view (instead of the current meme/default image).
Add the newly user-attached image file to the static assets directory exactly as-is at frontend/public/assets/generated/ with the exact filename "kanni 14-2.PNG".

Add the newly uploaded image file (provided by the user as "kanni 14-3.PNG") to the static assets directory at frontend/public/assets/generated/ and ensure it is available at runtime under the exact filename "kanni 14.PNG".

projectName: Romantic Valentine prompt page with evasive No button and meme reveal
